Summary:
The patient's chief complaint and 24-hour events are not provided in the given progress note. However, the note indicates that the patient was admitted to the ICU with an initial heart rate of 160 beats per minute and was started on diltiazem, metoprolol, lorazepam, and a normal saline bolus.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 101.4°F (Tmax and Tcurrent), heart rate ranging from 130s to 80s on diltiazem drip, blood pressure ranging from 136/67 to 159/105 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%.

The patient's heart rhythm is currently sinus rhythm. Fluid balance shows a total input of 1754 mL (366 mL PO, 120 mL TF, 1344 mL IVF) and a total output of 1420 mL (500 mL urine, 920 mL unknown), resulting in a balance of 334 mL.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 6.4 K/uL, hemoglobin of 12.0 g/dL, platelet count of 83 K/uL, creatinine of 0.8 mg/dL, and glucose of 121 mg/dL. Other lab values such as calcium, magnesium, and phosphate levels are also mentioned.

The patient's peripheral vascular examination is incomplete, with no assessment of radial or digital pulses.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment and Plan:
   60 y/o M s/p fall down and EtOH intox found to have comminuted
   fractures of the right tibia and the fibula.
   .
   # Afib/flutter with RVR: Patient with first ECG that looked like 2:1
   flutter and repeat after slowing down in ED that looked like A-fib.
   Likely RVR in setting of pain and EtOH intox as well as questionable
   intake of medications.  Patient is having difficulty taking PO
   medications and heart rate control was not acheived on the floor.  He
   does respond to both diltiezem and metoprolol IV.  As he was previously
   on metoprolol PO as outpatient will continue BB for AV nodal blockage.
   -Currently well rate controlled on dilt drip.
   -continue home 50mg metoprolol PO.
   - IVF PRN.
   -Holding anticoagulation in periop setting.  Likely can just start
   aspirin daily.
   -Continue to monitor for symptoms of withdraw/intox.
   -Pain control.
   -Per EP, would go for TEE/Cardioversion if rate control cannot be
   achieved with dilt drip.
   .
   # Ankle fracture: Needs to go to OR for ? staged procedure.
   - appreciate ortho recs
   - pain management with IV dilaudid.
   - NPO for now
   .
   # Preop risk assessment: Patient needs the procedure for pain control
   per Ortho team. Moderate risk procedure. Will need to optimize his
   heart rate prior to going to the procedure.
   - continue betablockade, needs RVR under control prior to going to OR
   - please see below for further details of risk assessment
   .
   # Per patient the last drink was on [**2176-12-21**] in the afternoon.  No
   recorded EtOH level at this time.  Unclear if patient is currently
   intoxicated or withdrawing.  The timeframe and tremor indicate
   withdraw.  However he is having slurred/mumbling speech which could
   support intoxication.  His elevated HR and pain are also confusing the
   picture.  He is not hallucinating or hypertensive.  Putting all of this
   together he is likely just starting to go through withdraw from EtOH.
   Will continue with symptom based benzodiazepine administration.
   - Continue CIWA with valium 5mg PO for CIWA > 10 q2h prn
   - F/u serum and urine tox for any evidence of other ingestions.  Also
   EtOH level from am may be useful in assess current toxicity v.
   withdraw.
   - thiamine/folate/MVI
   .
   # N/V: Nonbloody and nonbilious. ? secondary to pain. Normal abd exam
   is reassuring but will need to rule out alcoholic hepatitis or
   pancreatitis.
   - check LFTs and lipase
   - NPO for now
   - odensetron IV prn
   .
   # Anemia: Macrocytic in an alcoholic patient. Probably secondary to
   nutritional deficiency.
   - guaic stools
   - iron panel/B12/folate levels
   .
   # Throbocytopenia: Thought to be due to alcoholism.
   - continue to trend
   - transfuse for Plt < 20 or active bleeding
   - avoid heparin products for now
   .
   Per the Revised [**Doctor Last Name 3480**] cardiac risk index (RCRI), the 6 independent
   predictors of perioperative cardiac complications are:
   1) High-risk surgery (includes any intraperitoneal, intrathoracic,
   suprainguinal, or peripheral arterial vascular procedures)
   2) History of ischemic heart disease (h/o MI or positive stress test,
   current CP thought due to cardiac angina, use of nitrate therapy, or
   ppathological Q waves on EKG, but NOT including revascularization)
   3) History of Heart Failure
   4) Stroke
   5) preoperative treatment with insulin (eg IDDM)
   6) Creatinine >2.0 mg/dL
   .
   The perioperative rate of cardiac death, nonfatal myocardial
   infarction, and nonfatal cardiac arrest is approximately:
   .
   No risk factors - 0.4 percent (95% CI 0.1-0.8 percent)
   One risk factor - 1.0 percent (95% CI 0.5-1.4 percent)
   Two risk factors - 2.4 percent (95% CI 1.3-3.5 percent)
   Three or more risk factors - 5.4 percent (95% CI 2.8-7.9 percent)
   ([**Location (un) **], TH, [**Doctor Last Name 10710**], ER, [**Last Name (un) 10711**], CM, et [**Doctor Last Name **], Circulation [**2165**];
   100:1043)
   .
   By adding beta blocker therapy, this risk can be reduced to:
   No risk factors - <1% (versus 0.4 to 1.0%)
   One to two risk factors - 0.8 to 1.6% (versus 2.2 to 6.6%)
   Three or more risk factors - >3% (versus >9 %)
   (Auerbach, A, [**Doctor Last Name 3480**], L. Circulation [**2172**]; 113:1361)
   .
   This patient has 0 risk factors, and hence has a 0.4% risk of
   perioperative cardiac complications.
   .
   He will need to be continued on betablockade periprocedure especially
   in the setting of of Atrial fibrillation/ atrial flutter with RVR.
   Needs RVR undercontrol prior to patient going to OR.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old male who presented to the hospital with a history of EtOH intoxication and sustained comminuted fractures of the right tibia and fibula from a fall. The patient has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and is currently being treated with diltiazem and metoprolol IV. The patient's heart rate has been well controlled on the diltiazem drip.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 101.4°F, blood pressure of 136/67 mmHg, heart rate of 91 bpm, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient's heart rhythm is currently in sinus rhythm.

The patient's lab results show a white blood cell count of 6.4 K/uL, hematocrit of 33.9%, platelet count of 83 K/uL, creatinine level of 0.8 mg/dL, and glucose level of 121 mg/dL. Other labs, including calcium, magnesium, and phosphate levels, are within normal range.

The patient's pain is being managed with IV dilaudid, and he is NPO (nothing by mouth) at the moment. The patient is at moderate risk for perioperative cardiac complications, but this risk can be reduced with continued beta-blocker therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include further

Summary:
Summary of the progress note:
- The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of alcohol intoxication and comminuted fractures of the right tibia and fibula.
- The patient was initially diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR), but currently, the heart rhythm is in sinus rhythm.
- The patient is on diltiazem drip for rate control and will attempt to convert to boluses after surgery.
- The patient's pain is being managed with IV dilaudid.
- The patient has a history of ethanol intoxication, and his last drink was on [**2176-12-21**] in the afternoon.
- The patient is withdrawing from alcohol, as indicated by symptoms such as tremors and discomfort.
- The patient's elevated heart rate and pain may be confusing the clinical picture, but withdrawal is clearly playing a role.
- Symptom-based benzodiazepine administration is being continued, and CIWA at 10mg qH is being administered because the patient was not well controlled on 10mg q2h.
- Serum and urine tox screens have been ordered to check for other ingestions.
- Thiamine/folate/MVI supplementation is being provided.
- Nausea and vomiting are suspected to be secondary to pain and will need to be ruled out as possible causes of alcoholic hepatitis or pancreatitis.
- Liver function tests (LFTs) and lipase levels are being checked.
- The patient

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment and Plan:
   60 y/o M s/p fall down and EtOH intox found to have comminuted
   fractures of the right tibia and the fibula.
   .
   # Afib/flutter with RVR: Patient with first ECG that looked like 2:1
   flutter and repeat after slowing down in ED that looked like A-fib.
   Likely RVR in setting of pain and EtOH intox as well as questionable
   intake of medications.   As he is currently in sinus and responsive to
   diltiazem will stick with CCB for now.  We will attempt to convert from
   drip to boluses after surgery.  Will first have to wean drip.
   -Currently well rate controlled on dilt drip. Will attempt to convert
   to boluses and then PO dilt.  [**Month (only) 8**] become moot point if patient
   tachycardia and afib resolve with pain control/surgery/clearance of
   withdrawl period.
   -d/c home metoprolol for now
   - IVF PRN.
   -Holding anticoagulation in periop setting.  Re-start aspirin daily.
   -Continue to monitor for symptoms of withdraw/intox.
   -Pain control.
   -Per EP, would go for TEE/Cardioversion if rate control cannot be
   achieved with dilt drip though unlikely.
   .
   # Ankle fracture: OR today.
   - appreciate ortho recs
   - pain management with IV dilaudid.
   - NPO for now
   .
   # Pre-op risk assessment: Patient needs the procedure for pain control
   per Ortho team. Moderate risk procedure. Ok to go from our standpoint.
   - continue rate control with IV dilt for now
   - please see below for further details of risk assessment
   .
   # ETOH withdrawl - Per patient the last drink was on [**2176-12-21**] in the
   afternoon.  ETOH level of 33 on 27^th AM labs.  Patient clearly
   withdrawing at the moment.  His elevated HR and pain are confusing the
   picture, however withdrawl is clearly playing a large roll.  He is not
   hallucinating or hypertensive.  Will continue with symptom based
   benzodiazepine administration.
   - Continue CIWA at 10mg qH as was not well controlled on 10mg q2h.
   - Serum tox from 27^th shows only benzos (likely iatrogenic and ETOH of
   33), no utox on record
   - thiamine/folate/MVI
   .
   # N/V: Nonbloody and nonbilious. ? secondary to pain. Normal abd exam
   is reassuring but will need to rule out alcoholic hepatitis or
   pancreatitis.
   - check LFTs and lipase
   - NPO for now
   - odensetron IV prn
   .
   # Anemia: Macrocytic in an alcoholic patient. Probably secondary to
   nutritional deficiency.
   - guaic stools
   - iron panel/B12/folate levels
   .
   # Throbocytopenia: Thought to be due to alcoholism.
   - continue to trend
   - transfuse for Plt < 20 or active bleeding
   - avoid heparin products for now
   .
   Per the Revised [**Doctor Last Name 3480**] cardiac risk index (RCRI), the 6 independent
   predictors of perioperative cardiac complications are:
   1) High-risk surgery (includes any intraperitoneal, intrathoracic,
   suprainguinal, or peripheral arterial vascular procedures)
   2) History of ischemic heart disease (h/o MI or positive stress test,
   current CP thought due to cardiac angina, use of nitrate therapy, or
   ppathological Q waves on EKG, but NOT including revascularization)
   3) History of Heart Failure
   4) Stroke
   5) preoperative treatment with insulin (eg IDDM)
   6) Creatinine >2.0 mg/dL
   .
   The perioperative rate of cardiac death, nonfatal myocardial
   infarction, and nonfatal cardiac arrest is approximately:
   .
   No risk factors - 0.4 percent (95% CI 0.1-0.8 percent)
   One risk factor - 1.0 percent (95% CI 0.5-1.4 percent)
   Two risk factors - 2.4 percent (95% CI 1.3-3.5 percent)
   Three or more risk factors - 5.4 percent (95% CI 2.8-7.9 percent)
   ([**Location (un) **], TH, [**Doctor Last Name 10710**], ER, [**Last Name (un) 10711**], CM, et [**Doctor Last Name **], Circulation [**2165**];
   100:1043)
   .
   By adding beta blocker therapy, this risk can be reduced to:
   No risk factors - <1% (versus 0.4 to 1.0%)
   One to two risk factors - 0.8 to 1.6% (versus 2.2 to 6.6%)
   Three or more risk factors - >3% (versus >9 %)
   (Auerbach, A, [**Doctor Last Name 3480**], L. Circulation [**2172**]; 113:1361)
   .
   This patient has 0 risk factors, and hence has a 0.4% risk of
   perioperative cardiac complications.
   .
   He will need to be continued on betablockade periprocedure especially
   in the setting of of Atrial fibrillation/ atrial flutter with RVR.
   Needs RVR undercontrol prior to patient going to OR.
   ICU Care

   .

   .

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of alcohol abuse admitted to the ICU with a right ankle fracture complicated by alcohol withdrawal and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF with RVR). The patient underwent open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of the right ankle fracture, received antibiotics peri-operatively, and was started on DVT prophylaxis with Lovenox. Post-operatively, there was some bleeding around the surgical site, which is expected according to the orthopedics. The patient's atrial fibrillation transitioned to sinus rhythm most of the day while on diltiazem, but had a 14-beat run of ventricular tachycardia (VT) at 1600, which was asymptomatic. The patient's temperature spiked to 101.1 degrees Fahrenheit and blood cultures were sent earlier that day, so they were not repeated. The patient has no known drug allergies and received cefazolin for surgery. The patient is currently on various medications including enoxaparin (Lovenox), hydromorphone (Dilaudid), and other ICU medications. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the noted complications. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated blood pressure. The patient underwent open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of the right ankle, received two doses of Ancef peri-operatively, and was started on DVT prophylaxis with Lovenox. The patient experienced some bleeding around the surgical site, which is expected according to the orthopedic surgeon. The patient was also diagnosed with atrial fibrillation and is being transitioned to Diltiazem PO 60 mg QID. The patient had a 14-beat run of ventricular tachycardia but was asymptomatic with normal electrolytes. The patient's temperature spiked to 101.1°F and blood cultures were sent. The patient has no known drug allergies and is currently receiving various medications including Enoxaparin (Lovenox), Hydromorphone (Dilaudid), and other ICU medications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient's temperature has spiked to 101.1°F, indicating a possible infection. Blood cultures have been sent, but the results are pending. The patient's immunocompromised state due to alcohol abuse may increase the risk of infection.
2. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient is receiving DVT prophylaxis with Loven

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of alcohol abuse admitted to the ICU with a right ankle fracture, complicated by alcohol withdrawal and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient underwent an open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of the right ankle and received antibiotics peri-operatively. He is currently on prophylactic anticoagulation with Enoxaparin (Lovenox) and pain control with Hydromorphone (Dilaudid). The patient's vital signs show a slight elevation in temperature, but he is hemodynamically stable. Fluid balance shows an intake of 2,011 mL and output of 1,775 mL, resulting in a positive balance of 236 mL. The patient's labs indicate anemia and thrombocytopenia, which are likely related to alcoholism. Imaging studies are pending. Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of alcohol abuse admitted to the ICU for a right ankle fracture complicated by alcohol withdrawal and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient underwent open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of the right ankle fracture, received antibiotics peri-operatively, and received prophylactic anticoagulation for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient experienced some bleeding around the surgical site post-operatively, which is expected according to the orthopedic surgeon. The patient was also diagnosed with atrial fibrillation and is being transitioned to oral diltiazem. The patient had a brief run of ventricular tachycardia but was asymptomatic. The patient's temperature spiked to 101.1 degrees Fahrenheit and blood cultures were sent. The patient has no known drug allergies. The patient is receiving enoxaparin (Lovenox) for DVT prophylaxis, hydromorphone (Dilaudid) for pain management, and other medications as needed. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the new onset of atrial fibrillation. The patient's vital signs include a maximum temperature of 38.4 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 88 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 120/60 to 181/97 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%.
